message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation suggests familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which is caused by mutations in the APC gene. Mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes are associated with Lynch syndrome. Inactivation of RB1 gene causes retinoblastoma, and inactivation of BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of multiple adenomas in a young patient suggests Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP), which is caused by mutations in the APC gene. Mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes are associated with Lynch syndrome, which usually manifests as colon cancer. Inactivation of RB1 gene is associated with retinoblastoma, and inactivation of BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes is associated with breast and ovarian cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of multiple adenomas in the colon indicates familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which is caused by mutations of the APC gene. Mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes cause Lynch syndrome. Inactivation of RB1 gene causes retinoblastoma, and inactivation of BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes causes hereditary breast and ovarian cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Innumerable adenomas in the left side of the colon are characteristic of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which is caused by mutations of the APC gene. Mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes are associated with Lynch syndrome, which presents with fewer but larger adenomas throughout the colon. RB1 gene and BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are associated with other types of cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Innumerable adenomas in the left side of the colon is suggestive of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which is caused by a mutation in the APC gene. Mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes are associated with hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), which is more commonly associated with right-sided tumors. Inactivation of RB1 gene is associated with retinoblastoma, and inactivation of BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes is associated with breast and ovarian cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of innumerable adenomas in the left side of the colon suggests an underlying mechanism of mutations in the APC gene, which is associated with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP). Mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes are associated with Lynch Syndrome. Inactivation of RB1 gene is associated with Retinoblastoma, while inactivation of BRCA1/2 genes is associated with Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The innumerable adenomas in the left side of the colon suggest familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which is caused by mutations in the APC gene. Mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes are associated with Lynch syndrome, but usually present with fewer polyps. Inactivation of RB1 gene is associated with retinoblastoma, and inactivation of BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are associated with breast and ovarian cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Innumerable adenomas suggest a diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which is associated with mutations in the APC gene. Mutation in DNA mismatch repair genes leads to Lynch syndrome. Inactivation of RB1 gene and BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes lead to other types of cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of multiple adenomas in the left side of the colon suggests Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP), which is caused by mutations in the APC gene. DNA mismatch repair gene mutations are associated with hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer, while RB1 and BRCA1/2 gene mutations are associated with other forms of cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has multiple adenomas in the left side of the colon, which is characteristic of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). FAP is caused by mutations of the APC gene. Mutation in DNA mismatch repair genes is associated with hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer. Inactivation of RB1 gene is associated with retinoblastoma, while inactivation of BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes is associated with breast and ovarian cancer.
